The game has a similar gameplay to the Shinobi series. At the start of each level, players are given a choice of playing as 2 characters out of the available 4 (Including Nakamura Mondo from the aforementioned series) and the game features 5 levels in total. The story is told through cutscenes and a gory cutscene depicting how the protagonist dealt the finishing blow to the enemy is shown after defeating each boss. Each protagonist has their own weapons which can be short range or long range, as well as a special attack that deals extra damage to their foes. Both players and the enemies can block each other's attacks. Players may also swap their characters at any time to allow one of the protagonists to regain their special attack gauge.

sample_screenshots.caption: Loading screen with the players you've chosen.
The second character has a longer range attack, but his attacks are weaker so it takes more hits to defeat the enemy.
A bit of backstory before starting the game.
Loading the next area of the level.

title: Hissatsu!

description:
This compilation includes the following games:

  • Castle of Illusion Starring Mickey Mouse
  • QuackShot starring Donald Duck
title: Sega Ages I Love Mickey Mouse: Fushigi no Oshiro Daibōken / I Love Donald Duck: Guruzia Ou no Hihou

description: Elf o Karu Monotachi (エルフを狩るモノたち) is an adventure game for Sega Saturn console based on anime with the same title. While the anime has been localized to Those Who Hunt Elves title in English-speaking countries, the game itself is Japan-exclusive release. The story follows Junpei, Airi, and Ritsuko, who have been magically transported to fantasy new world. In order to return home, they have to find five spell fragments that have been placed on the skin of certain elves, which means in order to check which elf has the fragment they'll have to strip him or her naked. The story plays as a typical Japanese adventure game which feels like a visual novel with static backgrounds and characters, but also with a list of verb commands the player can click on each location (i.e. look, talk, move). The map shows each of the character and their locations and as the story progresses new locations become available. The game has full voice-acting and subtitle of spoken text can be turned off, otherwise they appear in a window with a name of currently talking character.
title: Elf o Karu Monotachi

alternate_titles.title: Revolutionary Girl Utena: Itsuka Kakumei Sareru Monogatari

description:
When a high school girl gets a sudden transfer to the prestigious boarding school her parents went to, she expects her life has nowhere to go but up. She's immediately thrust into the school's complicated political dynamics, where she has to ask herself: who is that strange, menacing girl who keeps showing up? What is this student council that seems to rule the school from the shadows? Why does someone seem to have it in for her? And why does it feel like there's something about their past her parents aren't telling her?

Based on the classic anime Revolutionary Girl Utena, this game lets the player experience surreal school life at Ohtori Academy. Instead of having the player take control of one of the show's characters, the game's protagonist is a brand-new character meeting the cast for the first time. Players can make alliances (and enemies) as they interact with characters and settle in; the story branches based on how characters feel about the protagonist, with nine possible endings and an enormous number of branching story paths. A page in the player's student handbook shows the player how every one of the main cast feels about her, letting the player be strategic with the route they take through the game.

Utena captures the show's aesthetic with art and music taken directly from the show alongside new artwork, cutscenes and music which match the original show's presentation. All dialogue is fully voice-acted with the original actors from the show reprising their roles, alongside new actors playing the game's original characters.
title: Shōjo Kakumei Utena: Itsuka Kakumei Sareru Monogatari

description: World Advanced Daisenryaku: Sakusen File is an entry in the Daisenryaku series with the campaign focusing on the eastern front during World War II. The game uses hexagonal grid over the battlefield map similar to that in the original Panzer General game. Available gameplay modes include standard mode and campaign mode. In standard mode the player can choose and play any map in single player or multiplayer and available selection of units is preset. In campaign mode, the player can go through Soviet story campaign which follows the actual historical events of WWII, or Cenozoic virtual campaign where any of the five available forces, namely US, British, Soviet, German, or Japanese, can be selected. During the campaigns the units evolve over time and upgrade into more powerful units that were developed during the course of World War II.
title: World Advanced Daisenryaku: Sakusen File

description: Soccer game for the SEGA Saturn by Konami, essentially a version of their International Superstar Soccer franchise that was well known on the N64 and PlayStation.
title: J. League Jikkyō Honō no Striker

description:
This pinball game has a 3D orientation in which the camera pans vertically wherever the ball moves or sometimes shows a closeup of the ball in rails and sinkholes. There are three different pinball tables:

  • Basketball Legend - Has the theme of a basketball court with coach-styled messages.
  • Card Master - Based on a casino theme, featuring poker and roulette.
  • Circus Fantasia - Displays a circus-styled theme with scoring for stunts.

The two modes in the game are the pinball mode, which feature only the pinball tables for the highest score or the story mode. In the story mode, a crippled basketball college student goes to a bar where he is inspired to become the best pinball champion player in the United States. The career-styled gameplay requires the player to make use of limited funds to make purchases, travel between cities and resting to stay healthy. Money is earned by beating opponents' scores in pinball or by winning a basketball mini-game.
title: Pinball Graffiti

description: This two-disc bundle contains copies of Puzzle Bobble 2X and Space Invaders bundled together in a cardboard slipcase.
title: Puzzle Bobble 2X & Space Invaders

description:
A compilation on one disc of the Japanese versions of the Arcade games ported to the Saturn:

  • Chase H.Q.
  • S.C.I.: Special Criminal Investigation
title: Chase H.Q. Plus S.C.I.

description:
This compilation features four Columns titles:

  • Columns
  • Columns II: The Voyage Through Time
  • Stack Columns
  • Columns 97

All titles are available for the Saturn for the first time through this release.
title: SEGA AGES: Columns Arcade Collection

description:
Jung Rhythm is a rhythm action game, whose gameplay is most closely reminiscent of PaRappa the Rapper or Space Channel 5. The player takes the role of Vanilla Essence, a young girl who dreams of being a star, and the story follows her quest from eating breakfast through to a duet with her favourite superstar, the puzzlingly named Mr. Chorking!

The gameplay itself takes the form of call-and-response dance and song duets with various characters, where the other character will sing a line and you’re asked to repeat it. Lyrics appear in a shaded box at the top of the screen, while input prompts appear in the first of a pair of bars along the bottom of the screen as they sing, and the player then repeats it on the second bar. Ad-libbed inputs are also permitted, and there are specific ad-lib segments.

Vanilla Essence’s performance is then graded in five categories and given an overall score. A score above 70 is a passing grade, and allows continuing to the next story segment. Between story segments there is a short full-motion video cutscene connecting the dots.

The game additionally includes a practice mode, as well as a 2-player battle mode, where two players can compare their skills.
title: Jung Rhythm

description:
Willy Wombat is an isometric action platformer. The camera is fixed from a top-down angle, but can be rotated using the shoulder buttons. Each stage features a series of intricate puzzles that stand in way of the exit at the end. Cutscenes are featured throughout, with fully voiced English dialogue.

The game takes place in an ideal society named Prison, where it's residents are able to essentially live forever without sickness through regeneration, however, this society is heavily regulated by their elite managers. One of Prison's managers, Willy Wombat, opts to escape this society in search of freedom in the land of Eden. To get there, he must search for six miracle gems, scattered across Prison. However, these gems attract deadly ghosts, who Willy must deal with using his set of attacks, including his boomerang. The other managers of Prison are also on Willy's tail, seeking to eliminate him. Essential items are scattered throughout these areas, like crystals, keys, and force powerups, that will aid Willy in his quest to find Eden.

sample_screenshots.caption: The save system. You need to collect badges in order to "buy" a save.

title: Willy Wombat

description: Stellar Assault SS is a 3D space combat shooter and a sequel to Stellar Assault. Like in the first game, you also controls a space fighter in a series of battles against huge enemy ships, but this time the gameplay is more story-driven, with supporting characters and voice acting. Stellar Assault SS was released exclusively in Japan.
title: Stellar Assault SS

description: Feda Remake updates the original Super Famicom version of FEDA: The Emblem of Justice with a fresh coat of paint and some gameplay tweaks. Aside from its enhanced graphics and sound, this remake now also features fully animated and voiced cutscenes for key points in the story. While the gameplay is largely the same as the original, there are several noteworthy tweaks: the alignment system has been updated to make it more challenging to reach the absolute good or absolute evil alignments; some characters feature additional special abilities; and two new characters have been added, one for each alignment.
title: FEDA Remake! The Emblem of Justice

description:
Crows: The Battle Action is a beat-'em-'up game based on Hiroshi Takahashi's delinquent manga series. Players can take control of one out 2 available characters, with 2 extra characters being unlockable as players clear the game.

Apart from the standard punches and kicks, the game offers special attacks which drain a bit of health when successfully used and a dash option as well. Weapons and objects can also be picked up and used against enemies. The game is linear, opting to put players through a lot of short stages which last for a few minutes before switching to a new one.

sample_screenshots.caption: Using a knife to attack them.

title: Crows: The Battle Action for SegaSaturn

description: This 3D sequel to Terra Cresta takes a simple, cut-down approach to shooting. Players blast off into space to take out waves of enemy spacecraft through several different levels. Most of the game is presented from an overhead view with a slightly tilted camera, giving the player a slightly longer view of the stage. A few stages switch the camera up to a chase camera, which is set behind the player's craft as they shoot at enemies as they fly towards the camera instead. There are three different craft, but unlike in most shooters players don't choose one at the beginning; instead, players can switch forms at any time to respond to the current situation. Unlike in most arcade-style shooters, there's no score whatsoever: the player's goal is simply to survive to the end of the game, not to reach any kind of high score.
title: Terra Cresta 3D

description: Taking inspirations from Yoshiki Tanaka's "Legend of the Galactic Heroes", the game consists of two divided human factions at war after an increasingly hostile colonization across the Milky Way. The player simply positions tactical units in airspace, configures their stats then assigns each unit specific commands. If decisions are done correctly, a successful strategy ensures a victory against all enemy units.
title: Gotha: Ismailia Seneki

description: Bulk Slash is a third-person action mecha simulation. The player assumes the role of Cress Dawley, the pilot of a transforming mech in a 3D level map with a boss at the end of each stage. A notable gameplay feature is the M.I.S.S. system: on every stage, a female navigator can be recruited and each one provides their own special abilities.
title: Bulk Slash

description: Koi no Summer Fantasy: in Miyazaki Seagaia is a dating simulation made to promote the Seagaia Ocean Dome. In it, players take idol Megumi Okina on a date through the eponymous water park, experiencing various attractions and making dialogue choices at pre-determined points in the story.
title: Koi no Summer Fantasy: in Miyazaki Seagaia

description: Album Club: Mune Kyun Saint Paulia Jogakuin is a game set in Japan that tells the story of a young schoolgirl and her robot through several mini-games such as Janken as she progresses through her daily activities, while the robot takes pictures of students for the school album. Cut-scenes take the form of anime and live-action.
title: Album Club: Mune Kyun Saint Paulia Jogakuin

description:
Ninja Jajamaru-kun: Onigiri Ninpōchō - Gold is a 3D platformer in the Ninja Jajamaru-kun series. It has gameplay similar to that of Ninja Jajamaru-kun: Onigiri Ninpōchō, in which players control the ninja protagonist Jajamaru-kun from a fixed behind-view perspective while using his throwable shuriken and katana to dispatch enemies, but with entirely different levels and enemies. The story once again follows Jajamaru-kun on a quest to rescue Princess Sakura from the clutches of Catfish Tayu. Like the previous game, levels contain power-ups for Jajamaru-kun to collect, and defeating enemies and collecting silver pieces awards points which add up to a score at the end of each level.

Although most of the game takes place in 3D environments, it also includes some 2D levels in the style of the original Ninja Jajamaru-kun game so that the 2D and 3D approaches to the series can be directly compared.
title: Ninja Jajamaru-kun: Onigiri Ninpōchō - Gold

description: Death Crimson is a first-person rail shooter. Doctor and former mercenary Combat Echizen has spent the past ten years researching KOT Syndrome, a disease that has spread across Europe and transformed countless people into monstrous creatures. Eventually, he learns of a connection between the disease and the Death Crimson - a mysterious gun he found in some ruins ten years prior during his time in the Marumara Army. Echizen then resolves to wield the Death Crimson (controlled by the player via light gun) against those infected with the Syndrome and get to the heart of what's going on.
title: Death Crimson

description: Tokimeki Mahjong Paradise: Koi no Tenpai Beat is a Mahjong tile-based game with two game modes. The Date Mode has the player competing against five girls to win their hearts. Each time they lose a match, the girls strip of some of their clothing in a cutscene, but whenever the player loses, they refuse any further favors. The Free Play allows the player to practice the game without any rewards for winning or consequences for losing.
title: Tokimeki Mahjong Paradise: Koi no Tenpai Beat

description: This port of Risky Challenge adds 34 more levels to the original 40. It also incorporates touched up cutscenes with voice-overs as well as intermission screens between levels.
title: Gussun Oyoyo-S

description: Based on the British children's picture book written and drawn by Raymond Briggs and published by Hamish Hamilton in 1973. It's a point and click adventure game that features video from the 1991 animated film adaptation.
title: Father Christmas

description: Mahjong Kyō Jidai Sexy Idol Hen is one of several games in Micronet's series of strip mahjong games featuring video footage of real-life models. This particular entry features video clips of three fashionable young idols, who progressively undress down to either their underwear or a swimsuit -- though no further -- as the player wins matches. The unlocked videos of each girl can be freely rewatched from the menu.
title: Mahjong Kaigan Monogatari: Mahjong Kyō Jidai Sexy Idol Hen

description: Mahjong Kyō Jidai: Cebu Island '96 is one of several games in Micronet's series of strip mahjong games featuring video footage of real-life models. This particular entry features video clips of three young ladies shot on the beaches of the Philippine island of Cebu. Winning mahjong matches against the girls will unlock videos of each girl in various swimsuits, which can be freely rewatched from the menu.
title: Mahjong Kyō Jidai: Cebu Island '96

description: In Vatlva, various duos pilot their vehicles in a top-down arena and try to take down their opponent with whatever weapons they have.
title: Vatlva

description: GT24 is an arcade-style racing game and a modified port of the 1996 arcade game Super GT 24h. It features one new track for a total of three in both regular and reverse configurations, two new vehicles for a total of six, and five different pit crews. Three game modes are included: Time Trial, Grand Prix, and a 24-hour Endurance race mode (which can be configured as 12, 24, or 48 minutes real time) that includes a full day/night cycle that changes as the race progresses.
title: GT24

description: Pyon Pyon Caruru no Mahjong Biyori is a family-friendly 1-on-1 style mahjong game featuring a cast of cutesy cartoon characters. Gameplay is a straightforward translation of Japanese-style reach mahjong with no notable additional features, and includes both a story mode with five playable (plus one unlockable) characters and a free match mode, along with a gallery featuring unlockable artwork of the characters.
title: Pyon Pyon Caruru no Mahjong Biyori

description: Solo Crisis is a strategy game for Saturn loosely inspired by the world-management sections of Quintet's ActRaiser. Gameplay takes place on a 3D game field, presented in via an isometric angle. The game world is divided into two sides, a light world on the upper half and a dark world on the flip side. Any changes made to the terrain of one side are reflected in inverse on the other side; for example, forming the land into a mountain on the light half produces a valley on the dark half. A portal between the two sides is present in one portion of each stage, providing a chance for both player units and enemies to pass through to the other side.
title: Solo Crisis

description: This title acts as an activity center based on the titular Lupin the 3rd. Contained in the CD are theme songs, character profiles with clips and information, maps of crime scenes, theme songs from the Lupin III movies, Story Digests providing Lupin III lore, and Drawings containing sketches of the anime in the works.
title: Lupin the 3rd: The Master File

description:
Clockwork Knight: Pepperouchau no Fukubukuro is a limited-edition compilation of Clockwork Knight and its sequel on a single disc, which includes a number of updates and bonus features:

  • Movie On Parade mode, which allows the player to watch any cutscene from either game.
  • Boss On Parade mode, which lets the player fight a boss rush of all boss encounters from each game.
  • In-game cutscenes are presented in higher video quality.

Also included in the package is a 1996 "3D calendar" featuring artwork from the game.
title: Clockwork Knight: Pepperouchau no Fukubukuro

description:
Shōgi Matsuri is a digital conversion of the traditional Japanese board game Shogi for one or two players, featuring the endorsement of the Japan Shogi Association (JSA), which has been the main organizing body for professional Shogi in Japan since 1924. In addition to standard play against another player or the computer at three skill levels, it includes a number of additional modes and options:

  • A tutorial for beginners to learn the basic rules of Shogi
  • Viewable recordings of over 1000 professional Shogi matches
  • A "next move" quiz where the player must choose the next move in 20 different situations (from a total of over 250), with the computer ranking the player's performance at the end
  • A tournament mode that simulates several prominent real-life Shogi tournaments
  • A prize mode where the player must solve several Shogi problems; successfully completing all of them displays a certificate that could be sent to the JSA for a Shogi-related prize
  • Komaochi Jōseki, or Piece Drop mode where the player can practice specific situations at a disadvantage against the computer
  • Tsume Shogi (Shogi Puzzle) mode with 400 problems at multiple difficulty levels to solve, including famous historical problems
  • Shogi Quiz where the player must answer 30 true-or-false questions about Shogi
  • A database of information about professional Shogi players circa 1995
title: Shōgi Matsuri

description: Pappara Paoon is a competitive color-matching puzzle game. Two players at opposite ends of a playfield launch colored pieces at a group of blocks; if four or more pieces of the same color are matched, all connected pieces of the same color are removed from play. Certain pieces will place garbage pieces on the opposing player's side of the board or shift the entire playfield in one direction, and if the pieces reach all the way to one end of the playfield, that player loses. The game includes both a single-player campaign mode and a two-player versus mode.
title: Pappara Paoon

description:
Heisei Tensai Bakabon: Susume! Bakabons is a competitive falling-block puzzle game based on the 1990 animated series Heisei Tensai Bakabon. Pairs of blocks in four colors drop from the top of the screen, and the goal is to line up two or more blocks of the same color, with another pair of a different matching color at either end. Any blocks on top of the ones cleared will fall into the open space, potentially comboing together into chains. Clearing multiple sets of blocks in a combo or chain will send garbage blocks to the opponent's playfield, and also charge up a super move that triggers automatically at a certain threshold which can clear a large number of blocks from the playfield.

The game has a single-player story mode in which Bakabon's dad, refusing to wake up in the morning, gets sucked up by his wife's vacuum cleaner and sent to a strange puzzle world where he must defeat the other characters from the show in puzzle battles. There is also a two-player versus mode with nine playable characters.
title: Heisei Tensai Bakabon: Susume! Bakabons

description: The Yakyūken Special is an updated port of a 3DO striptease game of the same name. As before, the player visits various models who challenge the player to a game of janken (rock-paper-scissors), doing a dance before making their move. Each time the player wins, the opponent removes an article of clothing, leaving her fully nude after five rounds. This version includes a total of twelve young ladies to challenge: the same eight from the original 3DO release, plus four new girls exclusive to this Saturn version.
title: The Yakyūken Special

description:
Haunted Casino is an adult-themed horror adventure gambling game. The player enters the titular "Haunted Casino", where a demon queen and her followers -- all of them attractive women -- lure in and trap unsuspecting men as their playthings. The player must explore the mansion-like casino in first person, avoiding traps and looking for helpful items, and eventually find each of the demons to challenge them to various gambling games such as roulette and blackjack. As the player wins coins, the demons will gradually remove their clothing until they are completely nude, at which point they can be sealed within a playing card. If the player loses, then their soul is lost for eternity to the demon queen.

There are seven demons throughout the casino to find, each of whom has a particular game they like best. After sealing a particular demon, the player can visit a viewing room and spend coins to view various nude scenes of that girl. The game is divided into three floors, and after sealing all the demons on a floor, the player will receive a key that leads to the next one. The ultimate goal is to seal the demon queen on the third floor.
title: Haunted Casino

description:
Chibi Maruko-chan no Taisen Puzzle Dama is a falling-block puzzle game based on the children's manga and anime Chibi Maruko-chan. The game plays very similarly to Puyo Puyo: colored balls fall from the top of the well in pairs, and must be arranged and stacked by the player. If three or more of the same color touch, they will disappear from the board, causing any stacked on top to fall down into their place and potentially creating a combo. Clearing many balls at once will launch garbage balls at the opposing player, and each character has a different pattern for how garbage appears and what colors it consists of. Garbage balls will turn into regular balls after a ball in a neighboring space is cleared. If either player's stack reaches the top of their well, that player loses the round.

The game includes a single-player arcade mode against a series of computer opponents, as well as a two-player versus mode.
title: Chibi Maruko-chan no Taisen Puzzle Dama

description:
Kanzen Chūkei Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine ("Complete Broadcast Pro Baseball Greatest Nine") is a baseball game featuring featuring an NPB (Nippon Professional Baseball) license and all twelve teams and all players from the Central and Pacific Leagues of Japanese baseball for the 1995 season. It is the first game in Sega's flagship Greatest Nine series of Sega Saturn baseball games.

It is presented in a realistic visual style, including digitized photographs of all players. Several game modes are available, including Open Game (Exhibition), Pennant Race, and Tournament modes, as well as All-Star Game and Home Run Contest modes. The game also features a full Team Edit mode and a player information database.

A modified version featuring American MLB teams and players was released worldwide as World Series Baseball.
title: Kanzen Chūkei Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine

description:
Greatest Nine '96 is a baseball game featuring featuring an NPB (Nippon Professional Baseball) license and all twelve teams and all players from the Central and Pacific Leagues of Japanese baseball for the 1996 season, and the second game in the series after Kanzen Chūkei Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine.

The game is once again presented in a realistic visual style using digitized photographs of the players. The major changes over the previous game are updated rosters for the new season, and the addition of licensed real-world stadiums instead of the fictional ones found in the first game. Game modes available are identical to the previous title: Exhibition, Pennant Race, Tournament, All-Star, and Home Run Contest, plus a full Team Edit mode and player database.

A modified version featuring American MLB teams and players was released worldwide as World Series Baseball II.
title: Greatest Nine '96

description:
Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '97 is a baseball game featuring featuring an NPB (Nippon Professional Baseball) license and all twelve teams and all players from the Central and Pacific Leagues of Japanese baseball for the 1997 season, and the third game in Sega's Greatest Nine series of Sega Saturn baseball games.

The game features an overhauled visual style that uses fully-3D player models instead of the digitized sprites of the previous two games. Available modes are Open Game (Exhibition), Pennant Race, and Home Run Contest — the Tournament and All-Star modes have been removed. The Team Edit mode also returns, though the player database is no longer available. The Nagoya Dome and Osaka Dome stadiums — brand new at the time of the game's release — have also been added to the available real-life stadiums.

A modified version featuring American MLB teams and players was released internationally as World Series Baseball 98.
title: Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '97

description: Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '97: Make Miracle is an updated release of baseball game Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '97. This version adds a "1997 Pennant" mode that recreates the actual events of the 1997 season, updates the player rosters, and allows for changing the camera viewpoint during play. It is otherwise nearly identical to the original version of the game.
title: Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '97: Make Miracle

description:
Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '98 is a baseball game featuring featuring an NPB (Nippon Professional Baseball) license and all 12 teams and all players from the Central and Pacific Leagues of Japanese baseball for the 1998 season, and the fourth main game in Sega's Greatest Nine series of Sega Saturn baseball games.

The game is very similar to the previous year's entry, featuring the same visual style and all of the same game modes: Open Game (Exhibition), Pennant Race, Home Run Contest, and Team Edit. New in this entry is the so-called Narikiri Mode, a variant of Pennant Race where instead of controlling a full team, the player picks a single player from one team to control.
title: Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '98

description: Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '98: Summer Action is an updated release of baseball game Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '98. This version updates the player rosters to the most current data as of the end of the 1998 season, adds additional original teams, and adds additional management features to the Narikiri Mode introduced in the previous release. It is the last entry in the series to appear on the Sega Saturn.
title: Pro Yakyū Greatest Nine '98: Summer Action

description: Jissen Mahjong is a 4-player riichi mahjong game that offers both 2D and full-3D visuals of the mahjong table. The game includes three modes: Challenge Mode tasks the player with defeating various opponents to increase their rank; while Free Battle Mode and Party Mode let the player choose any three of the 10 available opponents and play a regular match with various options. There are also a wide range of configuration options for adjusting the game rules.
title: Jissen Mahjong

description:
Godzilla: Rettō Shinkan is an isometric-view real-time strategy game based on the famous kaiju monster movie series created by Toho. The player controls the JSDF forces and must attempt to repel Godzilla and other monsters, protecting Japan from destruction.

Each mission contains a different map, scenario, and set of monsters to fight off. The player can select to various military vehicles and issue various commands to each, such as to move to a specific location or attack a particular target. Multiple monsters often appear on the same map, and may even fight against each other — not necessarily a good thing as they may cause immense collateral damage. To clear a stage, the player must defeat all monsters on the stage before either their forces are depleted or the city sustains too much damage.

The game includes a story scenario with 10 missions, as well as a free mission mode with an additional 10 missions.
title: Godzilla: Rettō Shinkan

description:
In the year 2061, technological advancements have allowed humans to surpass the limits of the weak human body. A new form of entertainment called Neo Pro Wrestling, which allows combatants to use powered armor and other enhancements, is rapidly gaining in popularity. The Pretty Four are a team of teenage wrestlers/pop idols, riding high after their newest member, Miku, snatched a world championship victory. Suddenly, a new tournament is announced by a mysterious new group called The Lion's Den, and Miku and the Pretty Four decide to take on the challenge.

Metal Fighter Miku is a Japanese-style adventure/simulation game based on the 1994 animated series of the same name. It features a new scenario in six chapters set six months after the events of the show, essentially functioning as a sequel. The player controls Miku and must develop her abilities and ultimately win each match as the story progresses.

The game is divided into two main sections. Most of the story plays out in standard visual novel-style dialogue sequences, with occasional choices that affect the flow of the conversation. Wrestling matches play out as real-time sequences where the player must select actions from a menu; available actions and current fighter status are shown at the bottom of the screen, while the top of the screen shows large illustrations of the match in action. Matches can be decided by pinfall, count out, or submission.
title: Metal Fighter Miku

description: Mahō no Janshi: Poe Poe Poemy is a 1-on-1 riichi mahjong game with a magical-girl anime theme. Various villains are causing trouble, and the magical girl Poemy must put a stop to their wicked ways by defeating them at strip mahjong. The game includes a story mode with anime cutscenes where defeating each opponent causes them to be disrobed – defeat them three times and they'll be left in only their underwear – as well as a free battle mode against any of the first three story opponents.
title: Mahō no Janshi: Poe Poe Poemy

description:
Mobile Suit Gundam is a side-scrolling action game based on the popular 1979 animated series of the same title and its three film adaptations, casting the player as the series' main character, the young pilot Amuro Ray. The story generally follows the plot of the films with only minor changes, and includes new animation from the original animation studio Sunrise that remakes famous scenes from the original.

The player pilots the titular RX-78-2 Gundam in both ground-based run-and-gun and space-based flight stages, using various weapons to destroy enemies; Radio chatter from other characters plays throughout each stage, and it is often necessary to destroy all enemies in an area to advance the story. As missions are completed, additional weapons become available and the player can customize their equipment loadout before each stage. Of special note is the Newtype Attack, which when charged and locked on will deal instant damage to targeted enemies, including enemies in the foreground and background outside the range of normal attacks.
title: Mobile Suit Gundam

description:
Far in the future, humanity has spread across the galaxy, and following a long period of war, peace finally came after a treaty between the 10 great powers of the galaxy. It has been 99 years since then, and peace has prospered. On the 100th anniversary of the treaty, a new peacekeeping fleet not controlled by any one power is being established to strengthen galactic peace. But some of the nations are planning a rebellion, and the students joining this new fleet are about to be swept up in something much greater than they could have ever imagined.

Quovadis is a turn-based isometric sci-fi war strategy game. The player controls a fleet of up to eight space warships that gradually increases in size and capability, eventually expanding to multiple fleets with different capabilities. In each mission, the player must issue commands to each ship, with the goal of defeating all enemy ships.
title: QuoVadis

description: My Best Friends: St. Andrew Jogakuen-hen is a anime-style jigsaw puzzle game with mild erotic content. The player meets up with various pretty young ladies at their school, attempting to woo them with jigsaw puzzle prowess. Each of the eight girls has multiple snapshots that appear as a puzzle, and completing the puzzle will reward the player with an animated scene of that girl; if the player can complete the puzzle quickly enough, the animated scene will show the girl topless, and the player will also get that girl's phone number to view the scene again. After gathering all eight phone numbers, an additional topless puzzle image is unlocked for each of the girls.
title: My Best Friends: St. Andrew Jogakuen-hen

alternate_titles.title: The Battle of Iron Chef: Kitchen Stadium Tour

description: Ryōri no Tetsujin: Kitchen Stadium Tour is an interactive multimedia experience based on the popular television show known internationally as Iron Chef. The main feature is a full-3D recreation of the show's "Kitchen Stadium" set, which the player can walk around freely. By interacting with various portraits or objects, the player can view interview clips with the cast and staff, see short clips from the show, and learn more about the contestants and the equipment used in the kitchen. There is also a museum mode that shows winning contestants from the show along with their dishes and ingredients, and other various memorable clips from the show. Last, there is a quiz mode that tests the player's knowledge of the show with 50 multiple-choice questions.
title: Ryōri no Tetsujin: Kitchen Stadium Tour

description:
PD Ultraman Link is a falling-block puzzle game featuring the Japanese superhero Ultraman and many of his allies and foes. Blocks of various colors fall into the well in pairs; each block has two connections, and connecting three or more blocks together regardless of color will cause them to disappear. Any blocks above the ones removed will fall into the now-open space, potentially creating chain combos which will send garbage blocks that must be cleared twice to the opponent. Additionally, connecting four blocks of the same color will clear all blocks of that color from the board, while connecting four each of a different color together will clear all the garbage blocks on the screen by one stage. If the blocks stack past the line at the top of the well, that player loses the match.

The game includes a single-player story mode, as well as a free battle mode against the computer or another player. There are 10 different characters to choose from: five Ultra Heroes and five aliens.
title: PD Ultraman Link

description:
Hinako, Kana, and Wakaba are three high school girls and the best of friends. One day they're goofing around at a shrine taking photos, and accidentally break a seal and release 108 spirits that had been sealed there. These spirits are terribly mischievous, and even turn one of the girls' classmates -- who was with them taking the photos -- into a strange mystical gem! The old man who watches over the shrine confronts the girls, telling them that it's their fault that the spirits escaped. They are each granted a secret transformation power that allows them to fight the sprits, and now it's their responsibility to capture the spirits and seal them back up again.

Omakase! Savers is a comedy adventure game featuring live-action scenes. The player takes the role of the girls' classmate, who appears as a small ghost, and must guide the girls in their quest to seal the spirits again and restore their classmate to his human form. This primarily takes the form of exploring the town on foot, talking to the townsfolk and investigating to find the whereabouts of the spirits causing trouble. Occasional combat takes a semi-real-time format, with the player moving around freely but pausing to perform attacks.

The game is divided into four chapters, each focusing on a specific spirit that must be defeated and captured. The characters in the game are represented both by anime-style sprites and digitized photo portraits of real actors, while numerous live-action cutscenes drive the story.
title: Omakase! Savers

description:
This bundle package includes the following items:

  • Virtua Cop game
  • Stunner light gun (called Virtua Gun outside North America)
title: Virtua Cop (Stunner Bundle)

description: J.League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurō! is a football (soccer) management simulation game and the first game in Sega's long-running management sim series. The player takes the role of the owner of a new Japanese football club and must build it from the ground up into a competitive team, with the ultimate goal of the club being admitted to the top league in the country, the prestigious J.League. With only a limited amount of funds available per year, the player must hire staff and scout players, manage sponsorships and publicity, schedule matches and training, and even chose the team's hometown and uniform colors.
title: J.League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurō!

description: J.League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurō! 2 is a football (soccer) management simulation game and the sequel to the first game in Sega's long-running series. The player takes the part of the owner of an upcoming club that is just about to join the prestigious J.League soccer league. As in the previous game, the player manages staff hiring and player scouting, sponsorships and publicity, match and training scheduling, and of course choose the team's hometown and uniforms. New in this entry are the ability to create up to three custom players for the team, additional options for post-match publicity and commentary, and a completely revamped in-game match display system that lets the player watch each match in a much more realistic style.
title: J.League Pro Soccer Club o Tsukurō! 2

description:
Tenchi and his friends are having a karaoke party! But Ryoko is hogging the mic and not giving anyone else a turn, and Ayeka is fed up with her hogging the spotlight. Washu suggests a game to decide who gets to sing next, but it's not nearly as simple as a game of janken...

Tenchi Muyō! Rensa Hitsuyō is a competitive falling-block puzzle game based on the Tenchi Muyo! anime series, similar to the popular Puyo Puyo series. Pairs of blocks in various colors fall into the playfield, and the player must arrange them; if three or more of the same color are matched together, they will vanish from the playfield and allow blocks above them to fall into their place and potentially trigger combo chains. Combo chains will cause the water level in the opponent's playfield to rise; blocks cannot be dropped below the water line, and if either the blocks or the water reach the top of the playfield that player loses the match. Several other special blocks also appear on occasion: Heart blocks will lower the water level when matched, Anchor blocks will push any blocks below them down into the water, and Ryo-oki blocks will trigger the selected character's special move when matched.

The game includes a single-player story mode, a two-player battle mode, and a free battle mode against the CPU, as well as a tutorial that explains the game rules. There are six playable characters, all of them the girls from the show; Tenchi himself is not playable.
title: Tenchi Muyō! Rensa Hitsuyō

description:
Hissatsu Pachinko Collection is a pachinko simulation game featuring recreations of six real-life pachinko machines licensed from pachinko manufacturers Daiichi and Fuji: Dance Dance 2, Arejin, CR Big Slotter 2, Sunrise, Excite, and Arrange Man.

The main game mode is a simulation mode where the player visits various pachinko parlors which each have their own operating hours and sets of machines. In addition to playing various machines with the goal of winning as much as possible, the player can also return home to rest or play a round of mahjong against the computer. In addition, there is also a free play mode where the player can practice on any specific machine with a variety of options, as well as an online competition mode where the player enters a password from a (now-discontinued) online service to compete with other players.
title: Hissatsu Pachinko Collection

description: Ninku: Tsuyoki na Yatsura no Daigekitotsu! is a one-on-one fighting game based on the manga and anime series Ninku. It features cel-animated characters on 3D backgrounds and includes eight playable characters from the series. The game is a versus fighter in the vein of Street Fighter II, and each character has a variety of unique moves, as well as special moves that can only be executed when their special power bar has enough charge. There is a single-player arcade mode and a two-player versus mode.
title: Ninku: Tsuyoki na Yatsura no Daigekitotsu!

description: mediaROMancer Daisuke Asakura is a multimedia fan disc for Japanese musician Daisuke Asakura. It includes a discography, interview clips, a breakdown of his studio equipment, and a plethora of photographs, video clips, and other information about him. In addition, there is also a game mode in which Asakura's manager has been kidnapped by a bandit, and Asakura must save him by hitting a specified number of targets in a whack-a-mole style minigame. Clearing stages in this minigame unlocks additional bonus video clips.
title: mediaROMancer: Daisuke Asakura

description:
Brain Battle Q is a quiz game which offers real-life prizes. The main game has the player enter the "Sega Saturn Invitational" quiz contest, playing through several rounds of a multiple-choice quiz contest against computer opponents. Upon completing the finals, the player is ranked based on their accuracy and speed, and given a password to send on a postcard included with the game to register their score with the publisher. The top five players each month through April 1997 received a prize.

In addition to the main contest mode, there is also a free quiz battle mode for one or two players. The player can select which types of quiz questions they want to see, as well as the difficulty level. There is also an in-game catalog for Japanese department store Seibu, which the game was produced in collaboration with, and which displays many of their real-life products for 1996.
title: Brain Battle Q

description: Virtua Photo Studio is a live-action photo shoot game similar to the earlier Virtual Cameraman series from the same developers. The player chooses from one of three models and does a photo shoot with them; this takes the form of taking pictures as a video plays, which are saved for later viewing. After each shoot, the model will change into increasingly revealing outfits — from cosplay to lingerie to a "bonus" nude shoot.
title: Virtua Photo Studio

description:
Shukudai ga Tant-R is a compilation of two SEGA arcade games:

  • Puzzle & Action: Tant-R
  • Quiz Shukudai o Wasuremashita

Each game has three difficulty settings but there are no other configuration options. This is the only release of either game on the Sega Saturn, and is also the very first release to feature the "Sega Ages" branding for Sega's classic game reissues.
title: Shukudai ga Tant-R

description:
Rōka ni Ichidant-R is a compilation of two SEGA arcade games:

  • Puzzle & Action: Ichidant-R
  • Quiz Rōka ni Tattenasai

Ichidant-R has three difficulty settings, and both games allow the player to set their number of starting credits. This is the only release of either game on the Sega Saturn.
title: Rōka ni Ichidant-R

description: Angel Paradise Vol.1: Sakaki Yūko - Koi no Yokan in Hollywood is a puzzle game featuring live-action video clips of gravure model Yuko Sakaki. There are two types of puzzles: jigsaw puzzles where the player must pick up and place pieces in the correct place to fill in portions of the video, and sliding-tile puzzles where a certain portion of the video must be correctly arranged. The main story mode is presented as the four days of a travelogue visiting Hollywood, California; each day includes two video puzzles of each type, plus a "bonus stage" which consists of an extra video of photo of Sakaki. There is also a data room mode where one can read various personal facts about her, and the options menu also lets the player peruse any completed videos and photos.
title: Angel Paradise Vol.1: Sakaki Yūko - Koi no Yokan in Hollywood

description:
Leon is a young boy of 16 who lives in Barcelona, and the son of the famous adventurer Fal Aventura. One day, the wreckage of his father's ship washes up on the shores of the city and, in order to find out what happened to his father, the young Leon sets out on a voyage of his own. Trusting that his father is still alive somewhere, Leon leaves to explore the world by sea, searching for the truth.

Daibōken: Saint Elmos no Kiseki is a seafaring pirate-themed JRPG similar to Koei's Uncharted Waters series. The game is roughly divided up into two main sections: sea travel, and on-foot town exploration, which each also have their own dedicated mode of combat. On-foot combat plays out in standard JRPG style, with the player choosing an action for each member of their party and watching as the results play out. Naval combat on the other hand takes a semi-real-time format where the player directs each ship in their fleet, issuing commands to attempt to sink all enemy ships, then board the lead ship and take out the captain in standard combat.

Most towns are infested with monsters when first reached, and the monsters must be defeated before the player can explore the town properly. Towns contain many types of businesses, such as inns and shops, taverns where crewmen can be recruited, and shipyards where the player's ship can be upgraded in both offensive and defensive capabilities. In addition to equipping the ship's crew, the player must also ensure they have enough resources such as food and clean water for each voyage.
title: Daibōken: Saint Elmos no Kiseki

description:
Jissen Pachinko Hisshōhō! Twin is a pachinko simulation game in Sammy's long-running series of gambling sims. This particular release features faithful recreations of two contemporary real-life pachinko machines made by Sammy:

  • CR Gao Gao Kids 4, a dinosaur-themed machine
  • CR Kudamonobatake, a fruit-themed machine

The game includes two play modes. The "Real Battle Simulation" mode lets the player set up custom pachinko parlors and must play the machines as they are laid out, starting with a certain amount of money and attempting to increase their winnings. This mode includes detailed tracking of the player's progress and performance. The "Complete Strategy" mode lets the player view detailed information about either machine and play it freely to practice without any money or time restrictions.
title: Jissen Pachinko Hisshōhō! Twin

description:
Jissen! Pachi-Slot Hisshōhō! Iron Hook is a pachi-slot (Japanese slot machine) simulation game and part of Sammy's long-running series of gambling sims. It features a faithful recreation of the Iron Hook slot machine made by Sammy, a pirate-themed machine which was brand new at the time of release. There are two modes: Simulation Mode lets the player choose a particular machine setup and freely play to practice, including detailed progression and stat tracking; Game Mode gives the player a set of pre-configured situations each with a strict time limit and must clear the requirements of each in order.

The game was not sold in stores, but rather was only available as a prize either from certain pachinko halls, or from contests held by publisher Sammy. It comes in an oversize package made to look like an old book with a treasure map inside, matching the pirate theme of the game. Additionally, players could enter a further contest to win pirate-themed prizes like a hand hook or a bottle of rum.
title: Jissen! Pachi-Slot Hisshōhō! Iron Hook

description:
Jissen Pachi-Slot Hisshōhō! 3 is a pachi-slot (Japanese slot machine) simulation game and part of Sammy's long-running series of gambling sims. It features a faithful recreation of five different real-life slot machines from various manufacturers: Aladdin Master by Sammy, Divers XX by Yamasa, Flipper 3 by Universal, Play Girl Queen 2 by Olympia, and Any 7 A by Takasago.

The main game mode is the "Real Battle" mode, in which the player selects one of five characters who each have different income and hours they are able to play, and must conquer a series of gambling halls by successfully earning enough winnings within a certain time limit. There is also the "Strategy" mode which lets the player select any configuration of any of the five featured machines, and practice without any time or money limits. Both modes include detailed progression and stat tracking.
title: Jissen Pachi-Slot Hisshōhō! 3

description:
Jissen! Pachi-Slot Hisshōhō! 4 is a pachi-slot (Japanese slot machine) simulation game and part of Sammy's long-running series of gambling sims. It features a faithful recreation of three different real-life slot machines from two manufacturers: Cranky Condor by Universal, 50's by Sammy, and Aladdin Master X by Sammy.

The main game mode is the "Trial" mode, in which the player enters a custom gambling hall and must earn winnings on each machine inside it. There is also the "Simulation" mode which lets the player select any configuration of any of the three featured machines, and practice without any time or money limits. Both modes include detailed progression and stat tracking.
title: Jissen! Pachi-Slot Hisshōhō! 4

description: Big Ichigeki! Pachi-Slot Daikōryaku: Universal Museum is a pachi-slot (Japanese slot machine) gambling simulation game. It includes faithful recreations of a total of 12 different slot machines from manufacturer Universal, both then-contemporary machines and also older ones from the company's long history of gambling machines. There is no campaign mode, but each machine offers multiple machine setups and there is detailed stat and progression tracking.
title: Big Ichigeki! Pachi-Slot Daikōryaku: Universal Museum

description:
The world of Rapyulus is one not unlike our own, except that if you wish to ask something of someone, you must defeat them in a game first. Rapyulus has always been a peaceful land, but recently strange things have been happening, and it's suspected that something may have happened to the goddess who watches over the land. A young man as recently come to Rapyulus, and it's up to him to figure out just what's going on and save this land from evil... but if he's going to get any help, he'll need to win a lot of games!

Bishōjo Variety Game: Rapyulus Panic is a mini-game collection featuring a cast of cute anime girls. The story mode consists of four themed areas each with three minigames -- and three girls to challenge -- for 12 games in total. Minigames include casino games like roulette and blackjack, jigsaw and sliding tile puzzles, spot-the-difference games, and even action challenges such as shooting incoming asteroids with a space ship. There is also a free game mode where any mini-games unlocked through the story mode can be freely replayed.
title: Bishōjo Variety Game: Rapyulus Panic

description:
This bundle contains two games at a reduced price:

  • Bishōjo Variety Game: Rapyulus Panic
  • Tsūkai!! Slot Shooting

Both games are identical to their original retail releases, simply packaged together in a paper sleeve.
title: Special Gift Pack

description:
Delisoba Deluxe is an action driving game in which the player must drive a scooter to deliver soba noodles while avoiding obstacles. It is a promotional tie-in based on a popular game called Delisoba (short for "Delivery Soba") on the TV variety show Sekiguchi Hiroshi no Tokyo Friend Park II broadcast by TBS between 1994 and 2011. On the original show, one player controls the scooter in a video game, while the other player sits on the back of a simulated scooter; if the first player crashes in the game, the second player feels the impact on the scooter and has to try not to drop the delivery.

The "TV Original" mode replicates the Delisoba experience from the show, tasking the player with reaching the end of the course within the time limit, avoiding obstacles such as other cars, banana peels, and angry cows, to deliver the noodles to the TBS television building in Tokyo. There are also several extra modes: a "Time Attack" mode that tracks the player's best times, a "Coin Links" mode where the player collects coins strewn across the track for points, an Arrange mode where various options can be changed such as adding special items or changing the max speed of the scooter, and a Track Edit mode where custom courses can be made.
title: Delisoba Deluxe

description:
Game-Ware is a multimedia "digital magazine", and the first release in the quarterly series of the same title. This first volume includes several playable game demos and original minigames:

  • Series of Dreams, a short branching text adventure where the player is a young man named Akira, who must make choices as he converses with two women: his girlfriend Shoko, and a mysterious girl named Megumi.

  • Pipit Boy no Daibōken, a puzzle game where the player must guide a boy to collect all the gems on each stage; the boy follows whatever path he walks along, and the player rotates tiles to direct him around the map.

  • Ejihon no Tantei Jimusho, a conversion of a "spot the different" style arcade game for up to four players where the player is shown an image filled with many kanji characters and must locate the one that does not match.

  • Telecom Town, a simple side-scrolling action game sponsored by Nihon Telecom in which a boy named Mamoru must collect stolen telephone cards to save the titular Telecom Town.

  • HG Cup, an action game sponsored by cosmetics company Shiseido in which the penguin Rocky must use hair gel and mousse to find all the checkpoints and clear the course as quickly as possible.

  • A playable demo of Digital Pinball: Last Gladiators which includes a single table, "Warlock".

Also included is a variety of multimedia content such as creator interviews, game previews, and an art gallery.
title: Game-Ware

description:
Game-Ware Vol.2 is a multimedia "digital magazine", and the second release in the quarterly series of the same title. This volume includes several playable game demos and original minigames:

  • Aoi Mizu no Naka, a suspense-horror adventure game with live-action video and photographs.

  • Pipit Boy no Daibōken 2, a sequel to the puzzle game in the first volume in which the player must guide a boy to collect all the bones on each stage; the boy follows whatever path he walks along, and the player rotates tiles to direct him around the map.

  • Telecom Town II, a simple side-scrolling shooter where the player shoots telephone cards as their projectile, and a sequel to the Nihon Telecom-sponsored game in the previous volume.

  • Cinderella Cruising, a top-down driving game sponsored by Mitsubishi in which the player, just married and on the way home from their wedding, must drive their wife home in their brand new Mitsubishi Challenger SUV within a time limit.

  • A playable demo of Layer Section.

Also included is a variety of multimedia content such as creator interviews, game previews, and an art gallery. This edition also includes the first chapter of the Virtua Fighter digital comic, "Legend of Sara".
title: Game-Ware Vol.2

description:
Game-Ware Vol.3 is a multimedia "digital magazine", and the third release in the quarterly series of the same title. As usual, this volume includes several playable game demos and original minigames:

  • Ejihon, a "spot the different" style game for one or two players which returns from the first volume with new puzzle pictures, where the player is shown an image filled with many kanji characters and must locate the one that does not match.

  • Onii-san, a simple point-and-click comedy adventure game.

  • Pipit Boy no Daibōken 3, a continuation of the puzzle games found in the previous releases; the goal is still to guide the boy to collect all the objects on the screen, but it is now a falling-block puzzle game where two players compete to build a path for the boy.

  • Protector Man: The King of Space, a simple Breakout-style game sponsored by razor company Schick.

Also included is a variety of multimedia content such as creator interviews, game previews, and an art gallery. This edition also includes the second chapter of the Virtua Fighter digital comic, "Legend of Sara".
title: Game-Ware Vol.3

description:
Game-Ware Vol.4 is a multimedia "digital magazine", and the fourth release in the quarterly series of the same title. This edition is the first to come on two discs rather than just one, and includes significantly more content than previous volumes. As usual, this volume includes several playable game demos and original minigames:

  • Pipit Boy no Daibōken 4, a continuation of the puzzle game series found in the previous volumes. This edition lets the player player Pipit Boy directly for the first time, as the game is now an auto-scrolling, top-down action game similar to Bump 'N' Jump, in which the player must collect small creatures to use as ammo while avoiding enemies and obstacles.

  • Ejihon, a "spot the difference"-style game for one or two players in which the player is shown an image filled with many kanji characters and must locate the one that does not match; this version continues the story and contains new picture puzzles.

  • Barbara Konomi's Sūsenjutsu, a numerology fortunetelling game.

  • Gondola-kun, a competitive window-washing game for one or two players where each player must avoid constant obstacles and be the first to wash all the windows on their building.

  • Otanoshimi Slot, a slot machine where the player can bet coins earned from viewing other contents on the disc; earning enough coins will give the player a password to enter a contest to win real-life prizes.

  • Yuppii no Puzzle Land, a competitive puzzle game in which two players try to match objects on the screen based on various criteria such as name or color.

  • Onii-san, a simple point-and-click comedy adventure game which returns for a second part to continue the story.

  • A playable demo of Digital Pinball: Necronomicon.

Also included is a variety of multimedia content such as game previews, and an art gallery, though the focus on these elements has been reduced in favor of interactive game content. This edition also includes the third and final chapter of the Virtua Fighter digital comic, "Legend of Sara".
title: Game-Ware Vol.4

description:
Game-Ware Vol.5 is a multimedia "digital magazine", and the fifth and final release in the quarterly series of the same title. As usual, this volume includes several playable game demos and original minigames, with many ongoing series reaching their conclusion:

  • Pipit Boy no Daibōken 5, the conclusion of the Pipit Boy series. This final edition takes the form of a simple action game where the player must target and reel in creatures and powerups while avoiding attacks, with the goal of reaching a quota before the other player.

  • Ejihon, a "spot the different" style game in which the player is shown an image filled with many kanji characters and must locate the one that does not match; as usual, this version includes numerous new picture puzzles.

  • The final chapter of Onii-san, a simple point-and-click comedy adventure game.

  • Barbara Konomi's Sūsenjutsu, a numerology fortunetelling game.

  • Toru Toru Marble, a puzzle game where the player must collect all objects on the field by only moving on the spaces where the items are contained, moving either one or two spaces forward at a time.

  • Otanoshimi Blackjack, a basic blackjack game where the player can bet coins earned from viewing other contents on the disc; earning enough coins will give the player a password to enter a contest to win real-life prizes.

  • Sekai Seifuku Kabushiki Gaisha ("World Conquest Corporation"), a simple strategy simulation game where the player must manage an army of monsters in order to conquer the world within the time limit.

  • A playable demo of Quovadis 2: Wakusei Kyōshū Ovan Rei.

Also included is a variety of multimedia content such as creator interviews, game previews, and an art gallery.
title: Game-Ware Vol.5

description: Kurubushi Kyōdai Gekijō Dai-ikkan: Mahjong-hen ("Ankle Brothers Theater Volume 1: Mahjong Edition") is a 4-player reach mahjong game featuring a cast of bizarre cartoon characters. The main story mode has the player complete a series of matches against randomly-selected opponents; each of the playable characters has their own story campaign with several chapters, all of which are suitably strange and told via still illustrations. There is also a free battle mode where the player can set up a match with any of the eight characters and customize the game rules.
title: Kurubushi Kyōdai Gekijō Dai-ikkan: Mahjong-hen

description: This limited-edition release of Mahjong Dōkyūsei Special includes a bonus disc with a gallery of production artwork.
title: Mahjong Dōkyūsei Special (Portrait CG-tsuki Shokai Genteiban)

description: Tokimeki Mahjong Graffiti: Toshishita no Tenshi-tachi is a strip mahjong game and the follow-up to Tokimeki Mahjong Paradise. While nominally a sequel, it features a completely different cast of new characters. It is a standard 2-player riichi mahjong game with a variety of rules options. The main mode is "Date Mode", in which the player must earn enough points by winning at mahjong to cause each girl to remove their clothing in fully-animated scenes. There is also a free battle mode and a "Memories" mode where completed reward scenes can be reviewed.
title: Tokimeki Mahjong Graffiti: Toshishita no Tenshi-tachi

description: This limited-edition package includes Hyper 3D Taisen Battle Gebockers along with a serial Link Cable accessory.
title: Hyper 3D Taisen Battle Gebockers (Taisen Cable-tsuki Gentei Pack)

description:
This limited-edition release of Idol-Mahjong Final Romance R includes the game along with two bonus items:

  • A "dress-up" game disc which lets the player dress each up each of the girls in various outfits, including new voice lines.
  • A booklet of concept and production artwork.

The dress-up disc was also given out as a separate promotional item, but the art book is unique to this release.
title: Idol-Mahjong Final Romance R (Premium Package)

description: This limited-edition release of Real Mahjong Adventure: Umi e Summer Waltz was only sold via Seta's Super Real Mahjong fan club and includes the game along with a CD soundtrack. The game disc also has full-color artwork unique to this release.
title: Real Mahjong Adventure: Umi e Summer Waltz (P's Club Genteiban)

description: Aquazone: Desktop Life is an aquarium simulation based on the earlier computer version. The player creates an aquarium and decorates it with plants, gravel and various objects, putting several types of tropical fish inside which swim around and act just like real fish. This initial release includes three different species of fish which can be placed in the aquarium. The player must also care for their fish, supplying food and medicine, changing and cleaning the water, and ensuring proper equipment is present.
title: Aquazone: Desktop Life

description: This expansion disc for Aquazone: Desktop Life adds the Angel Fish as an additional species of fish the player can add to their aquarium, plus some new decorative objects for the tank. It requires the base game to use.
title: Aquazone Option Disc Series 1: Angel Fish

description: This expansion disc for Aquazone: Desktop Life adds the Black Molly as an additional species of fish the player can add to their aquarium, plus some new decorative objects for the tank. It requires the base game to use.
title: Aquazone Option Disc Series 2: Black Molly

description: This expansion disc for Aquazone: Desktop Life adds the Blue Emperor as an additional species of fish the player can add to their aquarium, plus some new decorative objects for the tank. It requires the base game to use.
title: Aquazone Option Disc Series 3: Blue Emperor

description: This expansion disc for Aquazone: Desktop Life adds the Clown Loach as an additional species of fish the player can add to their aquarium, plus some new decorative objects for the tank. It requires the base game to use.
title: Aquazone Option Disc Series 4: Clown Loach

description: This expansion disc for Aquazone: Desktop Life adds the False Rummy-Nose as an additional species of fish the player can add to their aquarium, plus some new decorative objects for the tank. It requires the base game to use.
title: Aquazone Option Disc Series 5: False Rummy-Nose

description:
This bundle packages two of Koei's Japanese-history simulation games together at a budget price:

  • Taikō Risshiden II
  • Nobunaga no Yabō: Tenshōki
title: Hideyoshi Nobunaga Set

description:
This bundle packages two of Sega / SystemSoft's Daisenryaku strategy games together at a budget price:

  • World Advanced Daisenryaku: Kōtetsu no Senpū (Iron Storm)
  • World Advanced Daisenryaku: Sakusen File
title: Daisenryaku Pack

description:
This bundle packages the first two Panzer Dragoon games together at a budget price:

  • Panzer Dragoon
  • Panzer Dragoon II: Zwei
title: Panzer Dragoon I & II

description:
Tenchi and the many beautiful ladies who live with him are going on vacation! On Ryoko's insistence, the group is off to a hot springs resort... but not just any hot springs, they're traveling to an entire hot springs planet! However, once they get there, it turns out Ryoko doesn't actually know where the resort is. Add in a mysterious young girl named Mimiri, and it's going to be an adventure for Tenchi and his friends just trying to have a relaxing vacation.

Tenchi Muyō! Mimiri Onsen: Yukemuri no Tabi is a Japanese-style adventure game based on the Tenchi Muyo anime series. The game is fully-voiced, not including even a dialogue display or subtitles, and progresses as is standard for Japanese adventure games. In each scene, the player can inspect various parts of the scene, move between locations, and talk to each of Tenchi's companions, with the story generally progressing after all relevant options have been exhausted. There are ten different endings depending on the player's choices and who they decide to talk to.
title: Tenchi Muyō! Mimiri Onsen: Yukemuri no Tabi

description: Gal Jan is an arcade-style strip mahjong game. It is a standard 1-on-1 riichi mahjong game, and notably uses rotoscoped animation of real actresses for the opponents. The game features only a standard arcade mode where the player plays against each opponent in order. There are three opponents to face, who each progressively disrobe in animated sequences as the player wins matches against them.
title: Yōen Denshi Mahjong Yūgi Gal Jan

description:
Mahjong Hyper Reaction R is a one-on-one strip mahjong game and a home conversion of Mahjong Hyper Reaction. This version is significantly expanded over the original arcade game and includes new content and features:

  • A new opponent, Yuka, has been added for a total of three girls to play against.
  • New animated opening and ending sequences.
  • A new "Free Battle" mode where the player can unlock newly-drawn illustrations of each girl.
title: Mahjong Hyper Reaction R

description:
Bakuretsu Hunter is a Japanese-style adventure game based on the anime & manga series of the same title (known as Sorcerer Hunters outside Japan). The game follows roughly the same story as the TV show, expanded with new content and animated sequences: the main character Carrot Glacé, along with his brother Marron, and the sisters Tira and Chocola, are so-called "Sorcerer Hunters" who serve the church to track down and exact punishment on Sorcerers who use their magic to commit evil acts against other humans.

The game proceeds mostly in a visual novel style, with voiced story sequences occasionally broken up with dialogue choices. There are also two mini-games which represent battles: a flag-raising minigame where the player must raise or lower the correct flag within the time limit, and a slot-machine battle where the results of the slot machine determine which actions each combatant takes. Both mini-games can also be freely played from the menu.

The game was only released as a "limited edition" version, which includes a poster and a bonus disc that contains voice actor interviews and an illustration gallery.
title: Bakuretsu Hunter

description:
Carrot, Marron, and the sisters Tira and Chocola are what are known as "Sorcerer Hunters": warriors who serve the church to punish those who would use magic for evil against other humans. Recently, several Sorcerer Hunters were found dead in the capitol, and Carrot and his team have been sent there to investigate these so-called "Sorcerer Hunter Hunters".

Bakuretsu Hunter R is a Japanese-style adventure game based on the anime & manga series Bakuretsu Hunter. The game is divided into eight chapters, and looks at a glance like a Japanese-style RPG with turn-based battles and top-down exploration. However, the RPG elements are purely superficial; there is no experience or character growth system, no inventory to manage, and while it is possible to die, all encounters are scripted as part of each chapter's progression. There are also several different mini-games which appear throughout the story and can also be played from the main menu.
title: Bakuretsu Hunter R

description: Heiwa Pachinko Sōshingeki is a pachinko simulation game featuring recreations of four real-life pachinko machines licensed from pachinko manufacturer Heiwa: CD Meiga, CD Ryujin, Daisangen, and Hayabusa. The main game mode has the player visiting various pachinko parlors to play each of the machines and attempt to win as much as possible. The game also includes two customization modes: the first lets the player adjust the arrangement of the pins on each board, while the second lets the player combine various layouts and background graphics to create a custom machine.
title: Heiwa Pachinko Sōshingeki

description: Shunsai is a horse racing database and simulation software which includes detailed race records for Japanese horse racing between January 1986 and April 1996. The main features are the database of race and horse information, as well as a simulator in which the player can select one of many famous races, along with a lineup of real-life horses to simulate the results of that race. There is also a quiz mode with three difficulty levels which tests the player's knowledge of horse racing.
title: Shunsai

description: Japan Super Bass Classic '96 is a bass fishing game endorsed by pro bass fisher Katsutaka Imae. The player is tasked with winning various tournaments on order to win professional titles; winnings can be used to buy and upgrade equipment, with the player's rod, reel, line and lure all being customizable. The game also includes a practice mode to try out equipment before participating in a tournament.
title: Japan Super Bass Classic '96

alternate_titles.title: Kidō Senshi Gundam Gaiden I: Senritsu no Blue

description:
Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story I: Senritsu no Blue is a first-person action shooting game based on the popular Mobile Suit Gundam media franchise. Relatively unique among Gundam games, it tells an original story not adapted from another media, and is the first in a three-part trilogy. It is set during the One Year War, shortly after Operation Odessa; the player controls Earth Federation pilot Yuu Kajima, who alongside his teammates Philip Hughes and Summona Fulis are sent on missions with experimental Mobile Suits in order to collect data for production. The team encounters a mysterious blue Mobile Suit that seems bent on eradicating Yuu's team, and which seems to show up without warning.

The game is divided into five missions, each of which has specific objectives such as destroying a particular target or defending a specific structure or character. The story is told through radio communications during gameplay, and objectives may change as the mission progresses. There are no branching story paths or loadout customization, though the player is ranked at the end of each mission which has an effect on the overall ending. Save data can be carried over into the sequel.
title: Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story I: Senritsu no Blue

description: This limited-edition release of Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story I: Senritsu no Blue includes the game along with a limited-edition pin, packaged in a cardboard digipak.
title: Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story I: Senritsu no Blue (Shokai Press Tokushu Package Shiyō)

alternate_titles.title: Kidō Senshi Gundam Gaiden II: Ao o Uketsugu Mono

description:
Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story II: Ao o Uketsugu Mono is a first-person action shooting game based on the popular Mobile Suit Gundam media franchise. Relatively unique among Gundam games, it tells an original story not adapted from another media, and is second entry in a three-part trilogy, following after Senritsu no Blue. It once again casts the player as pilot Yuu Kajima, with the identity of the mysterious blue MS starting to be revealed.

The game is again divided into five missions, each of which has specific objectives such as destroying a particular target or defending a specific structure or character. The story is told through radio communications during gameplay, and objectives may change as the mission progresses. There are no branching story paths or loadout customization, though the player is ranked at the end of each mission which has an effect on the overall ending. Save data can be carried over from the first game, and into the third after completing all missions.

Two releases of the game exist: a standard edition in a jewel case and a limited edition in a cardboard digipak. Other than the packaging, the two releases are identical and there is no bonus content or extra items in the limited edition.
title: Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story II: Ao o Uketsugu Mono

alternate_titles.title: Kidō Senshi Gundam Gaiden III: Sabakareshi Mono

description:
Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story III: Sabakareshi Mono is a first-person action shooting game based on the popular Mobile Suit Gundam media franchise. Relatively unique among Gundam games, it tells an original story not adapted from another media, and is third and final entry in a three-part trilogy, following after Ao o Uketsugu Mono. This concluding chapter once again has the player controlling pilot Yuu Kajima. Two machines remain with the experimental EXAM System, designed to mechanize the abilities of Newtypes and allow human pilots to have the same capabilities: one has been stolen, purportedly by the pilot of the mysterious blue MS, Efreet; the other has been assigned to Yuu.

The game is again divided into five missions, each of which has specific objectives such as destroying a particular target or defending a specific structure or character. The story is told through radio communications during gameplay, and objectives may change as the mission progresses. There are no branching story paths or loadout customization, though the player is ranked at the end of each mission which has an effect on the overall ending. Save data can be carried over from the previous games, and the game's ending changes depending on the player's rank throughout the full campaign.

Two releases of the game exist: a standard edition in a jewel case and a limited edition in a cardboard digipak. Other than the packaging, the two releases are identical and there is no bonus content or extra items in the limited edition.
title: Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story III: Sabakareshi Mono

alternate_titles.title: Kidō Senshi Gundam Gaiden: The Blue Destiny

description:
Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story: The Blue Destiny collects together all three Saturn Gundam Side Story releases in a single package:

  • Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story I: Senritsu no Blue
  • Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story II: Ao o Uketsugu Mono
  • Mobile Suit Gundam Side Story III: Sabakareshi Mono
